Human development in more parts of the state has increased the risk of fires spreading into populated areas, such as LA . In California's recent history, wildfires have closed national parks, destroyed the state’s natural and cultural treasures, killed vulnerable residents, destroyed homes, and caused countless environmental issues ranging from mudslides to wildlife deaths to habitat and species loss . text_summary: Watch Duty is a nonprofit app that tracks wildfires with live maps and alerts . Users in 22 states can take advantage of evacuation warnings; real-time text, photo, and video updates . title: How wildlife survives after wildfires
description: The biggest danger for wildlife is the aftermath. But many species have evolved to rely on the opportunities created by others.
author: app.buzzsumo.com
text_summary: Fire is a serious problem for humans, particularly when they build in fire-prone areas . But there are surprisingly few animal fatalities as a direct result of fire . Many species have evolved to rely on the opportunities created by others . The Los Angeles wildfires that occurred in January 2025 are predicted to have cost in excess of $135bn (£109.7bn) How do different species eke out a living among the devastation? And in a world with increasingly large fires, exacerbated by global climate change, is there any way humans can help them? We would lose biodiversity if we did not have fire in our system, says Morgan Tingley, professor of evolutionary biology at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), .

author: DC Correspondent
text_summary: Investigators are examining multiple potential causes behind the devastating California wildfires that have claimed at least 11 lives and destroyed thousands of homes and businesses in the Los Angeles area . Lightning is the most common cause of wildfires in the U.S. No lightning activity was reported in the affected regions, including the terrain surrounding the Eaton Fire in East Los Angeles County . The California wildfires underscore the region’s vulnerability to devastating blazes, exacerbated by a combination of dry conditions, urban expansion, and diverse ignition sources . So far, there is no official indication of arson in either the Pacific Palisades or Eaton fires, but investigators are meticulously analyzing the origin points to determine whether human negligence or other factors played a role . As of Friday, both fires were still burning with minimal containment .

title: VERIFYING claims about inmates who fight wildfires in California
description: Over 1,100 incarcerated firefighters are helping fight the Los Angeles wildfires. Here’s what we can VERIFY about their pay and if they can get jobs upon rele...

text_summary: Several people on social media claim many of the firefighters are currently incarcerated . Some posts suggest that these incarcerated firefighters work for around $10 per day . Others allege these firefighters will not be able to get jobs as professional career firefighters upon release . California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) manages 35 fire camps across 25 counties in California . As of January 2025, there are currently 1,870 incarcerated persons working at fire camps throughout the state of California, and 1,600 of them are firefighting crew members . Incarcerated firefighters used to make up as much as 30% of the California wildfire force, but the numbers have dwindled over the years, largely due to state prison reform and the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a report .

For many it could be a harsh reality— stepping back from work altogether could be overworking as a distraction .
